title: First presidency of Donald Trump
deleted: On February 5, 2019, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to rebuke Trump for his decisions to [[American-led intervention in the Syrian Civil War#December 2018|withdraw troops from Syria]] and Afghanistan. Drafted by majority leader [[Mitch McConnell]], the measure was supported by nearly all Republicans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/us/politics/senate-vote-syria-afghanistan.html|title=Senate Rebukes Trump Over Troop Withdrawals From Syria and Afghanistan|first=Catie|last=Edmondson|date=January 31, 2019|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> On February 29, 2020, the Trump administration signed a conditional [[Afghan peace process|peace agreement with the Taliban]], which calls for the [[withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan]] in 14 months if the Taliban uphold the terms of the agreement.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/afghanistan-us-taliban-peace-deal-signing/2020/02/29/b952fb04-5a67-11ea-8efd-0f904bdd8057_story.html |title=U.S. signs peace deal with Taliban agreeing to full withdrawal of American troops from Afghanistan |last=George |first=Susannah |date=February 29, 2020 |newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump says 'it is time' for US troops to exit Afghanistan, undermining agreement with Taliban |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-time-us-troops-exit-afghanistan-undermining-agreement/story?id=70908619 |first1=Elizabeth |last1=McLaughlin |first2=Luis |last2=Martinez |first3=Conor |last3=Finnegan |publisher=ABC News |date=May 27, 2020}}</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: The following platforms have also banned or restricted Donald Trump: [[Facebook]], [[Google]], [[Spotify]], [[Snapchat]], [[Instagram]], [[Shopify]], [[Reddit]], [[Twitch (service)|Twitch]], [[YouTube]], [[TikTok]], [[Pinterest]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Discord (software)|Discord]]. <ref>{{citeweb|author1=Sara Fischer|author2=Ashley Gold|title=All the platforms that have banned or restricted Trump so far|url=https://www.axios.com/platforms-social-media-ban-restrict-trump-d9e44f3c-8366-4ba9-a8a1-7f3114f920f1.html|date=2021-01-08|access-date=January 9, 2021}}</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: The following platforms have also banned or restricted Donald Trump: [[Facebook]], [[Google]], [[Spotify]], [[Snapchat]], [[Instagram]], [[Shopify]], [[Reddit]], [[Twitch (service)|Twitch]], [[YouTube]], [[TikTok]], [[Pinterest]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Discord (software)|Discord]].<ref>{{citeweb|author1=Sara Fischer|author2=Ashley Gold|title=All the platforms that have banned or restricted Trump so far|url=https://www.axios.com/platforms-social-media-ban-restrict-trump-d9e44f3c-8366-4ba9-a8a1-7f3114f920f1.html|date=2021-01-08|access-date=January 9, 2021}}</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: From March to December 2020, a major [[cyberattack]] by a Russian [[Advanced persistent threat|hacking group]] affected several U.S. government departments, state governments, and large commercial companies. Trump delayed responding to the attack for several days, before suggesting it was Chinese in origin.

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
deleted: From March to December 2020, a major [[cyberattack]] by a Russian [[Advanced persistent threat|hacking group]] affected several U.S. government departments, state governments, and large commercial companies. Trump delayed responding to the attack for several days, before suggesting it was Chinese in origin.

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: From March to December 2020, a major [[cyberattack]] by a Russian [[Advanced persistent threat|hacking group]] affected several U.S. government departments, state governments, and large commercial companies. Trump delayed responding to the attack for several days, before suggesting it was Chinese in origin.{{cn}}

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
deleted: In May 2018, the administration dissolved a global health security team that was part of the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]], and which had been tasked with overseeing pandemic readiness.<ref name="NSC Exit The Hill">{{cite news |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/387191-trump-official-overseeing-pandemic-response-suddenly-leaves-admin |title=Trump official overseeing pandemic readiness exits |last1=Thomsen |first1=Jacqueline |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |access-date=February 26, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201105175454/https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/387191-trump-official-overseeing-pandemic-response-suddenly-leaves-admin |archive-date=November 5, 2020}}</ref> There were bipartisan calls from lawmakers and experts to restore the White House pandemic team.<ref name=":18">{{Cite news |last=Qiu |first=Linda |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/13/us/politics/fact-check-trump-coronavirus.html|title=Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus |date=March 13, 2020 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=March 16, 2020 |issn=0362-4331 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201119195032/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/13/us/politics/fact-check-trump-coronavirus.html |archive-date=November 19, 2020}}</ref> When Trump was asked during the COVID-19 pandemic why his administration dissolved the team, Trump said "I don't know anything about it."<ref name=":18" />

In September 2018, the Trump administration received detailed plans on how to mass-produce [[Protective mask|protective respirator masks]] under a program that had been launched by the Obama administration to alleviate a mask shortage for a future pandemic; the Trump administration choose not to act on those plans.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/federal-government-spent-millions-to-ramp-up-mask-readiness-but-that-isnt-helping-now/2020/04/03/d62dda5c-74fa-11ea-a9bd-9f8b593300d0_story.html |title=Federal government spent millions to ramp up mask readiness, but that isn't helping now |last=Swaine |first=Jon |date=April 3, 2020 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |url-status=live }}</ref> Two months before the coronavirus outbreak in China, the Trump administration ended a [[United States Agency for International Development|USAID]] project used to track and research [[Zoonosis|diseases that move from animal to human hosts]], and train nearly seven thousand people and strengthen medical laboratories in developing countries.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Baumgaertner |first1=Emily |last2=Rainey |first2=James |url=https://www.latimes.com/science/story/2020-04-02/coronavirus-trump-pandemic-program-viruses-detection |title=Trump administration ended pandemic early-warning program to detect coronaviruses |date=April 2, 2020 |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |language=en-US |access-date=April 3, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210103154422/https://www.latimes.com/science/story/2020-04-02/coronavirus-trump-pandemic-program-viruses-detection |archive-date=January 3, 2021}}</ref> The program, started after the [[Global spread of H5N1 in 2005|H5N1 bird flu in 2005]], had enjoyed enthusiastic support under both [[George W. Bush|Bush]] and Obama.<ref name="Vox Predict">{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2019/10/29/20936921/usaid-predict-pandemic-preparedness |title=A crucial federal program tracking dangerous diseases is shutting down |last1=Piper |first1=Kelsey |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |access-date=February 26, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210107200628/https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2019/10/29/20936921/usaid-predict-pandemic-preparedness |archive-date=January 7, 2021}}</ref> On February 10, 2020, during the early stages of the pandemic in the U.S., Trump's 2021 budget proposed cuts to global health programs in the magnitude of $3{{nbs}}billion,<ref name="Trump-Budget-2021-proposal">{{cite web |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/msar_fy21.pdf |title=A BUDGET FOR AMERICA'S FUTURE |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=February 2020 |website=www.whitehouse.gov |publisher=[[Office of Management and Budget]] |access-date=January 8, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201224190348/https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/msar_fy21.pdf |archive-date=December 24, 2020 }}</ref> including substantial cuts to the CDC budget and U.S. contributions to the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO).<ref name="Forbes CDC cut">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lisettevoytko/2020/02/11/trump-proposes-16-cut-to-cdc-as-global-number-of-coronavirus-infections-and-deaths-rise/ |title=Trump Proposes 16% Cut To CDC As Global Number Of Coronavirus Infections And Deaths Rise |last1=Voytko |first1=Lisette |website=[[Forbes]] |access-date=February 26, 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210105154158if_/https://www.forbes.com/sites/lisettevoytko/2020/02/11/trump-proposes-16-cut-to-cdc-as-global-number-of-coronavirus-infections-and-deaths-rise/ |archive-date=January 5, 2021}}</ref><ref name="ABS News global health cuts">{{cite web |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-budget-proposes-cuts-global-health-amid-global/story?id=68911515|title=Trump budget proposes cuts to global health amid two global health crises|last1=Finnegan|first1=Conor|website=[[ABC News]]|access-date=February 26, 2020}}</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
deleted: President Trump delivered his official farewell address the day prior to the [[inauguration of Joe Biden]], and referred to the "inauguration of a new administration".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://trumpwhitehouse.archives.gov/briefings-statements/remarks-president-trump-farewell-address-nation/ |title=Trump White House Archives — Briefings and Statements — Farewell Address}}</ref>

In keeping with tradition, Trump left Biden a letter of support in the [[Resolute desk|''Resolute'' desk]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Jackson|first=David|last2=Fritze|first2=John|date=January 20, 2021|title=Donald Trump leaves letter for Joe Biden ahead of inauguration|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/01/20/donald-trump-leaves-letter-joe-biden-inauguration-day/4228139001/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210120152944/https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/01/20/donald-trump-leaves-letter-joe-biden-inauguration-day/4228139001/|archive-date=January 20, 2021|access-date=January 20, 2021|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US}}</ref>.  When asked about the letter, Biden stated that it was "generous", but refused to give details.{{citation needed|date=January 2021}}

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: On January 8, Secretary of State [[Mike Pompeo]] met with Secretary-designate [[Antony Blinken]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/08/politics/pompeo-blinken-meeting-january/index.html |title=Pompeo met with Biden's secretary of state pick for first time |first1=Kylie |last1=Atwood |first2=Jennifer |last2=Hansler |website=CNN |date=January 8, 2021}} [[CNN]]</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
deleted: Prior to the election, [[Chris Christie]] was leader of Trump's [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump|transition team]]. After the election, Mike Pence replaced Christie as chairman of the transition team, while Christie became a vice-chairman alongside [[Jeff Sessions]], [[Michael Flynn]], [[Rudy Giuliani]], [[Ben Carson]], and [[Newt Gingrich]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Pence will lead Trump transition|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/11/11/politics/pence-will-lead-trump-transition/index.html|publisher=CNN|access-date=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
